title: For Sale:  M-735 ARMOR PIERCING (TANK KILLER) ROUND
postcontent:
The M-735 is a 105MM armor-piercing, fin-stabilized, discarding-sabot (APFSDS) cartridge. Other than the primer and the propellant, this cartridge uses no explosives. It is a high-velocity, flat-trajectory cartridge designed for use against armored targets. The projectile section consists of a sub-projectile, a sabot assembly, and a cartridge case. The sub-projectile is constructed of a nickel-steel body that houses a tungsten core with an aluminum windshield and fin assembly. The sabot assembly consists of three 120-degree aluminum sections assembled to the sub-projectile. These are still in use today.

I've had this piece in my collection for over 30 years. I obtained this while serving as an armor crewman with the 1st Cavalry Division back in the mid '70's.

HEIGHT: 19" 
WEIGHT: 10 lbs.

$130.00 or Best Offer. 
Call REDACTED or email REDACTED for any questions you may have.

For sale, my Mauser HSc 380 ACP semiauto pistol.  I bought this handgun in the late 1970's new as I have always been a Mauser fan and this was the last of the HSc models to be made.  It is offered as I received it with the presentation box, extra magazine, owner's manual, barrel brush, and Factory 3 shot test firing target.  I am also including my Bianchi belt holster.

The HSc is in excellent condition having been fired not that much, somewhere in the low hundreds rounds.  It has always been a reliable loader, able to handle both roundnose and hollow point ammunition.  I loaded most of what I shot myself and found, like a lot of semi autos, it likes a heavier load.  The only loading issues I had was in firing low power lead rounds.

The only flaw found is on the right side of the slide between the American Crest and the serial number are a few pinpoint impressions made when I got clumsy one time.  They are very hard to see, small and can be felt only by my fingernail, not finger pad.

Bluing is excellent, barrel is excellent, and it's all here.  A nice collectible that is also a great carry.

title: For Sale/Trade:  Stainless, Ported, 2.5" .357
postcontent:
I have a rare Rossi M971 VRC for sale/trade. It is a stainless 6 shot 357 with a 2.5" ported barrel. This gun is a K-frame sized pistol and has been my conceal carry for the last year. Its in great condition and shoots better that my S&W 686. Dont let the name Rossi fool you! You have never seen a gun like this! Comes with a nice leather paddle holster and speed loader.

The 971 VRC (which stands for Vent Rib Compensated) is a ported version of its 971 model, which, like all the Rossi revolver line, is based on the proven Smith & Wesson design. Heat-treated 400- series stainless steel is used for all major components. The barrel and frame are forged, while the cylinder is mach-lined from bar stock. The 971 VRC offers button-rifled, ported, fully-shrouded barrel.

Here is the write up: http://www.nramuseum.com/media/363997/Jan%2096.pdf

title: For Sale/Trade:  ANTIQUE   GUNS   RESTORED
postcontent:
Almost every family has great grandpa's old shotgun. It may have been in the family for generations! It is a keepsake but needs to be put into better shape. Parts may be missing or it won’t work. It may be rusty and the wooden parts deteriorated. You may simply want the old thing professionally cleaned -OR- Refurbished to a presentable state – OR - you may want it put into LIKE NEW shape! Perhaps you wish to present this family treasure, fully restored, for Christmas? Don't wait. It may take us DAYS to complete your project - once we get yours in line. 
We have a huge inventory or antique and hard-to-find parts along with hundreds of stocks and forearms. If we don’t have the antique part we may have to order it or – even MAKE it. As an example, most of the guns we restore are over 100 years old! For the time being at least, pre-1899 guns are completely EXEMPT from all federal laws. 
We can offer Professional Results. Your family heirloom will look, "Good as great Grandpa bought it!"
We are not a dealer and do not sell guns. However, we can restore your family treasure to its original out-of-the box appearance. Each project is priced based upon the level of complexity at the customer's request and the current condition of the piece. Most of our projects are old shotguns and rifles.
Reply to this website or call Jim @ REDACTED 
Email: REDACTED

title: For Sale:  Starr Arms .44cal Revolver - Civil War Army
postcontent:
Starr Arms .44 Caliber Army Double-Action Revolver
Genuine Civil War Relic!  (This is NOT a replica)

Serial Number 13327 (stamped into magazine and frame [under hammer])
Patent Date Jan 15, 1956 (stamped into the side of the frame)
Starr Arms Co, New York (stamped into the side of the frame)

I would describe the condition as good considering its vintage.  The company name, patent date, serial number and other markings can easily be read in various locations where they are stamped into the metal.  There is some pitting on the frame above the magazine cylinder from oxidation.  The outline of the inspectors mark can be seen faintly where it was stamped into the wood handle, but the inspectors initials are no longer visible.  The wooden handle has a some scratches and dents.

I researched the value of this item on the internet, and I have found that it typically retails for $1,500 or higher for this revolver in similar or better condition.  So I feel the price that I am asking represents a good deal.

Interested buyers can call/text telephone REDACTED.
_______________________________________________________________

Trivia - According to one website that I found while researching this item Clint Eastwood carried this sidearm in the movie “Unforgiven.”
_______________________________________________________________

I am providing several references here for your reading/viewing pleasure:

1.  http://www.gunsinternational.com/Star-Pistols.cfm?cat_id=110

2.  http://www.american-firearms.com/american-firearms/z-html/company-S/Starr%20Arms%20Company/Starr%20Arms%20Company.html

3.  http://armscollectors.com/mgs/starr_revolvers_week_2.htm

4.  http://www.nramuseum.com/the-museum/the-galleries/a-nation-asunder/case-38-arms-for-the-union-union-pistols/us-starr-arms-co-1858-double-action.aspx

Text found on reference #4:
“About 23,000 double-action Starr revolvers were manufactured in the late 1850s and early 1860s. Of these, most were purchased by the U.S. Army. Starr revolvers, in both single-and double-action models, represented over 12 percent of the sidearms issued to Union cavalry troops. Only Colt and Remington revolvers were more frequently encountered in the hands of Northern soldiers.

One of the earliest American double-action revolvers, this six-shot revolver has a six-inch round barrel rifled with six grooves. Over-all length is 11 5/8 inches, weight is two pounds 12 ounces, and the cylinder is 1 7/8 inches long. These revolvers have a steel blade front sight dovetailed into the barrel. A V-notch cut into the hammer lip serves as a rear sight. The Starr revolver is provided with a knurled screw on the right side of the frame which, when removed, allows the barrel to tip downwards on its hinged frame so that the cylinder can be removed.

Starr revolvers were invented by Eben Townsend Starr of New York City, grandson of Nathan Starr and son of Nathan Starr, Jr., famous U. S. swordmakers and riflemakers of Middletown, Connecticut. This model is marked on the right side of its frame "STARR'S PATENT JAN. 15, 1856.", and on the left side, "STARR. ARMS. Co. NEW YORK." The patent date refers to E. T. Starr's U. S. Patent 14,118 for a self-cocking percussion pepperbox. His U.S. Patent 30,843, December 4, 1860, was for his double-action revolver.

Starr firearms were made at Yonkers, Binghamton, and Morrisania, New York, from 1858 to 1867. The New York City address referred to the Starr Arms Company store and office at 267 Broadway. Starr double-action .44 caliber revolvers, with serial numbers from 1 to about 23,000, were manufactured first, and Starr single-action .44 caliber revolvers, with serial numbers from about 23,000 to about 54,000, last.”
